column1: As soon as she had gone
column2: Lady Windermere returned to the picture-gallery
column3: where a celebrated political economist was solemnly explaining the scientific theory of music to an indignant virtuoso from Hungary
column4: and began to talk to the Duchess of Paisley. She looked wonderfully beautiful with her grand ivory throat
column6: and her heavy coils of golden hair. Or pur they were — not that pale straw colour that nowadays usurps the gracious name of gold
column7: but such gold as is woven into sunbeams or hidden in strange amber; and gave to her face something of the frame of a saint
column8: with not a little of the fascination of a sinner. She was a curious psychological study. Early in life she had discovered the important truth that nothing looks so like innocence as an indiscretion; and by a series of reckless escapades
column10: she had acquired all the privileges of a personality. She had more than once changed her husband; indeed
column11: Debrett credits her with three marriages; but as she had never changed her lover
column12: the world had long ago ceased to talk scandal about her.
